awd_titl_txt: NSF/FDA Scholar in Residence Program on In Vitro Biological Characterization of 3D Printed Small-Scale Medical Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Narayan, Roger J.
Proposal: 1445727
Title: NSF/FDA Scholar in Residence Program on In Vitro Biological Characterization of 3D Printed Small-Scale Medical Devices

Significance
The data obtained in this project will serve as the basis for a material property-biological performance database, in which the relationship between in vitro cell-material interactions, protein adsorption, and material processing parameters will be considered. The regulatory science approach will provide a repertoire of methods and tools to understand the fundamental tissue-material interactions for complex and innovative device technologies.

Technical Description
In the proposed Scholar-in-Residence (SIR) program, a 3D printing technique known as multi-focus two photon polymerization will be used to create solid tissue barb adhesives with microscale features for tissue penetration and sub-microscale features for cell ingrowth out of a zirconium oxide hybrid material. Tissue barbs are innovative small-scale devices with potential use in wound closure and healing. They will examine use of biocompatible photoinitiators (e.g., riboflavin-triethanolamine mixtures and riboflavin-arginine mixtures) for two photon polymerization-based 3D printing. They will also evaluate incorporation of an electrochemical sensor for monitoring of creatinine within the tissue barb adhesive. In the proposed program, they will collaborate with FDA colleagues to evaluate the in vitro biocompatibility of tissue barb materials that contain sub-micrometer scale pores and creatinine sensor materials using appropriate cells (e.g., dermal fibroblasts and epidermal keratinocytes).
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The outcome of this program was the development of new materials and devices for transdermal biosensing. Microneedles are  50–900 micrometer tall lancet-shaped or hypodermic needle-shaped devices that may be used to draw fluid from the skin to detect biologically-relevant molecules. Due to the small dimensions of microneedles, tissue damage at the treatment site isminimized. Microneedles are associated with low levels of pain since these devices do not penetrate deeper layers of the skin. In one study, hollow and flexible metal microneedle arrays were created by combining micromolding and electroplating methods. Master polydimethylsiloxane molds were created by two photon polymerization of precursor solid microneedle structures. These molds were subsequently coated with a seed layer of titanium and gold. The molds were then electroplated to create hollow microneedles. The molds were capable of being utilized up to thirty times without damage; repeated microneedle array removal did not alter the functionality of the molds. The mechanical properties and porcine skin penetration properties of the electroformed microneedles were shown to be appropriate for transdermal use. In another study, microneedle platforms were combined with multifunctional lab-on-chip electrode arrays; in particular, microneedles were integrated with a platform that included fluidic channels and electrode transducers. Electrodes were made by photolithographic patterning; they were modified using diazonium chemistry for capture antibody immobilization. An electrochemical sandwich immunoassay protocol was used for detection of the cardiac proteins troponin and myoglobin; these proteins increase in concentration in peripheral fluid if the heart is damaged. A fluidic channel was used to transfer the solution from the microneedles to the electrodes. This immunoassay setup was successfully used for detection of myoglobin and troponin. This type of device is capable of performing real time measurements of interstitial fluid for detection of proteins associated with myocardial infarction (heart attack). Understanding the biocompatibility issues associated with 3D printed microneedles and transdermal electrochemical sensors will aid public health.
 


Last Modified: 11/06/2017
Modified by: Roger J Narayan
